lore-desertexcavation-piece1:
These decrepit walls are the only respite I get from the sweltering heat and the battering sand. Whenever the winds die down, I take my shovel and try again to unveil the entrance. But both the cold of night and heat of day demand that I take frequent breaks, and the equally frequent sandstorms quickly undo what little progress I am able to make.

I sit here at my fire journaling to pass the time, waiting for the next opportunity to dig, but in my heart I know this is a fool’s errand. I suspect this temple's entrance was sealed entirely, and it must be broken into by force. Force I currently do not possess. Whatever I find here will surely be enough to fund my next expedition, but without the funds to hire labourers I cannot hope to excavate it.

It cannot be helped. It would be irresponsible to stay any longer with my dwindling rations. Next dawn, when the temperature begins to rise, I will start my journey home. I’m no cartographer, but I will try my best to record the location, so that I might at least sell a map to someone better equipped.

I am well aware I am betraying my archeologist’s honor in giving a find like this up to the common graverobber! I can only hope my professors at the University will forgive me and understand my situation.
lore-allhandsrequired-piece1:
Let it be known across the realms that the Svanmarck Estate seeks able labourers for the construction of our Grand Waterways, a work destined to connect our lands by canal.

Workers of all trades - diggers, masons, carpenters, haulers - all shall receive fair salary and warm lodging, paid in full by the noble Svanmarck family.

Those willing to serve may travel to the twenty-third milestone past Yarrowford. Enter through the main gate of the Svanmarck Estate and ask to see Lady Elewyn to be directed to the works.

Signed,
Grand Architect Faulkner, 
Of International Acclaim
lore-paigeswoes-piece1:
Oh, how we sung high praises of how accessible our Waterways were!
The Svanmarck family had earned back our investment and then some, and the trade center has not even started construction yet. Lined our pockets with gold as we taxed those that crossed through the canal junction for all that they could afford to miss, and with an inland route so much swifter than on foot or by carriage, many of the high-profile traders would opt for our canals over the beaten path. Things were looking good and would only get better from here.

But then, why do good things never last!? 
I am uncertain still what Grand Architect Faulkner had been shouting from under that air vent. A warning, something about a quarantine, and an instruction to order the servants to bury the tool sheds that lead deeper underground, after which he had hastily scurried off. I did recall having felt the ground quake two hours or so earlier when I found a group of disgruntled merchantmen on my doorstep. They said that they had crashed their skiff into a large pile of rubble blocking the canal into the Waterways, damaging the ceramics they were meaning to sell. 

The wounds they had suffered were evidence enough, and I did not wish to further strain relations. Elewyn’s father had put full faith into Faulkner for all of his life and now I shall do much the same. I simply compensated the traders for their lost goods and lost time and then sent them on their way.___NEWPAGE___
lore-paigeswoes-piece2:
It has been over a fortnight! The treasury is beginning to feel the strain of the blocked-off Waterways. I will admit we are living quite lavishly, so that alone might be enough to drain it without new funds coming in, but again and again I find myself having to dig into our coffers to appease leagues of angry travellers who had come far and wide just to cross through our canals. I hire daytalers to drag their vessels out of the water and transport their goods overland and throw them a little gift of gold for their time because I understand they value theirs as much as I value my own, and more than that I understand the value of maintaining relations with traders. I can hear my partner in life and in business, dearest Elewyn, speak to them even now, reassuring them that everything will return to normal.

I was taught not to explain why the Waterways were off limits, because those traders are a persistent people, and they would see every reason presented as a challenge to argue against… though I did hear some speak with great disgust of a plague of Rot spreading across the lands. I will choose to believe it is merely a tale.
I am doing everything according to my mother’s lessons, but I must admit doubts are creeping in. Five times now have I tried to seek contact at the grates, but I could never see another across it. Each time I sensed only the scent of overripe vegetables, sickly sweet, piercing my nostrils, and then I turned away. I do hope Faulkner remains in good health.___NEWPAGE___
lore-paigeswoes-piece3:
I am catching my breath still, but I must immortalize this memory in ink lest it leaves me. By God, I hope it leaves me. I will save Elewyn the hurt and shoulder this burden alone.

Finally I saw a face at the grate again, or what was left of a face, having climbed up to the top of the vent. Skin sloughing, skull exposed, bone tainted red with dirt and blood, and it was impossible to tell where one starts and the other ends. I had smelt death before, and now it was staring me in the eyes. It was looking at me. I think it tried to vocalize, but all I heard was the horrid wail of scraping metal against stone as it reached out through the grate to claw at me. Fearing for my own life, I ran and commanded our last remaining servant to shovel soil unto the grate until it drowned out the noise. I understand what this meant, the weight of my request. Whatever remained alive down there was going to suffocate. At this point it was a small mercy. The most I could do for them still.

The memory is not leaving me. Worse yet, I know it did not mean to hurt me, that thing. Because I have seen people drown before, and that grasping I stood witness to was a perfect imitation of the final, desperate grasp for something to keep one’s head above water before they disappear below the surface for good.___NEWPAGE___
lore-paigeswoes-piece4:
I am leaving it all behind, these accursed Waterways and our derelict home above. It’s bad luck to build atop burial grounds, and I don’t intend to find out if that applies retroactively.

There’s nothing left for me here, anyway. I found Elewyn in catatonic state upon the sofa. She had been acting cold and irritable the week before. I thought the stress must be getting to her, but now I can tell; without her perfumes to overpower it that unmistakable stink now permeates our chambers.
I pray the Rot will take her swiftly. I did not have it in my heart to send her to God, myself.
If there is anybody left, I beg you, take my woes as warning and turn back whence you came.___NEWPAGE___
lore-paigespleas-piece1:
“Faulkner, I need to understand what’s going on here. What is the quarantine for?”
“Faulkner, the mercantile guilds are getting impatient. They want to know when they can have their people back. Do you have an estimate for when the quarantine ends?”
“Faulkner, perhaps you could enlist one of the quarantined to stand watch below the grate, and fetch you when they see me here. That way, we could speak again, even if we are both so busy. I have many questions to ask!” 
“Faulkner, is there anything I can do to aid you in your duty, to help the quarantine along? I can smell food that has gone bad through the air vent. I’ve dropped all the pouches of grain through the grate that I could spare. It is sure to last a lifetime.”
“Faulkner, it’s difficult to see down there, and my lantern’s light does not quite reach. I cannot tell if these are reaching you, but… I am choosing to believe they are. Know that I continue to pray for you.”
“Faulkner, I long for your guidance. Elewyn is in low spirits, and I had not realized how much my own hope was hinging on her smile. I wish we could speak again, but I understand you must be busy ensuring everything goes smoothly below.”
“Faulkner, I’m sorry.”
“Faulkner, I’m so sorry.”
lore-faulknersmusings-piece1:
What an ambitious project I have been saddled with.

A system of canals that connect this place to the rest of the world.

The task is simple, in essence. Digging canals is simple. But to dig so many is ambitious. Can’t all ambitious tasks be broken down into dozens upon dozens of simple ones?

Either way, I continue to amaze myself with the Svanmarck line’s ability to convince others to do their work for them. And I continue to be surprised that I’ve fallen for it again, too.

Really, I should not be complaining. Many hands make light work, and these Waterways would never have been possible if the surrounding settlements were not equally desperate for an aquatic route inland.___NEWPAGE___
lore-faulknersmusings-piece2:
Under any other circumstances, this would have been an impossible feat. But as expected, everything went swimmingly. Get it? Swimmingly? Because they’re canals full of water, and…

Nevermind that. The first stage of work is done, and now the second stage can begin. Our employers seemed very happy with our progress already.

Decisions have already been made by the Svanmarcks. We know how to proceed from here. The reservoir we have emptied will see metamorphosis into a true hub of commerce!

Even now it is sprawling with labourers, constructing walkways along the hollow’s edge, hewing what will become my office into rock and stone at its very bottom. It will be easier to sleep here than to travel daily. The workers look and act like ants, when viewed from above, and I their conductor.

Raw materials flow generously into the site from our suppliers, and calloused hands assemble them into walkways and scaffolds at unprecedented speeds. Never in my life have I seen a design of mine take shape so swiftly.___NEWPAGE___
lore-faulknersmusings-piece3:
Thrice now has a labourer fallen to the plague. I wish I could still set my quill to parchment with as much enthusiasm as I had done before. I am not certain who introduced it here, nor am I certain it matters. They came from at least three different towns. If the Rot is in all of them already, then… Well. I am only certain that harm will come to the Svanmarcks if I allow its spread to continue unchecked here. So I’ll simply not allow it.

Hope and Isaiah. Those are the names of the two Blackguard soldiers aiding me in enforcing my quarantine. They were here separately, each to safely escort a merchant of luxuries, but have heroically forsaken their duties in order to fulfill the one I have given them. I have a lot of respect for them, for doing what is needed where no-one else will. And mostly I am grateful they are on my side!

Elewyn and Paige do not yet know of the nature of the quarantine, but I have informed Paige through the air vent that there is one in place. I feel shame for letting it get to this point… I do not think I can face the Svanmarcks. Not before this is over. Beyond an architect I am an alchemist. I have all the reagents here I would need to seek a cure. Until then no-one will leave or enter. They will understand. They will have to. I’ve forced all paths in and out of the canal junction to collapse, including the staircase to the estate’s toolshed. Now my precious Waterways have become a lazaretto.___NEWPAGE___
lore-faulknersmusings-piece4:
Believe me, please believe me, I had best intentions at heart. This forsaken reservoir was meant to become a grand marketplace of splendor. Now it is a cesspit of plague. I do not know what is going on on the surface, anymore. I am not sure I want to. But I hope that through our sacrifice the estate is free of Rot.

Rot that spreads not only through body but also through mind. Perhaps the detainees were affected thus, explaining their outbursts of rage and threats on my life. And I refuse to believe the twin jailors were always so cruel in turn. Do not misunderstand me. It was certainly an effective way to shut things down. But I would like to take back what I wrote earlier. I have no respect for the Blackguard anymore. Only reverence, and healthy fear. 

I have felt watched as of late. Of course, all the quarantined look to me for a solution! It is my duty to deliver them a cure and their subsequent freedom, for I am the one that damned them to this fate. But the feeling of their hopeful eyes pleading me for aid does not leave me anymore. Even within the walls of my chambers I can still sense their gaze resting on me, from the moment I shut that door behind me. I can work like this no longer. I have thus forfeited my quarters to Hope and Isaiah at their request and withdrawn into an unfinished tunnel to continue my work in relative privacy, even with the little faith I possess in my own ability to outpace the black sick that has taken root in my bones.

Death would be a mercy for us now. I cannot envision anyone remaining in good health. Many have lost limbs. I can smell the necrosis below Isaiah’s armor. I had no idea just how bad things had gotten until I set foot inside the reservoir again, when I was escorted to my new worksite. Had I really spent so long locked away, only to make no progress at all, or had the disease simply spread at such a pace that I never stood a chance to begin with?

Gathering my resolve I will make my final attempts at synthesizing a cure. But I have made no progress from my starting point. None whatsoever. I must admit that in a moment of weakness I fashioned an ingested poison, and I pray that I will have the resolve to imbibe it now that I still possess the means.

Even the lowliest of architects have heard of the Panopticon. An experiment, a cruel design of prison, wherein a single person can see every single detainee all at once. But never until now had I considered the sheer quantity of eyes gazing back.___NEWPAGE___
lore-panopticonletters-piece1:
Even with all these folks suffering alongside me I’ve never felt more lonely.

The wardens see to that. Any attempt at fraternizing will be met with accusations of spreading the plague first and accusations of staging a rebellion second.  And it’ll see both parties made into a display for the rest.

I only hope the black sick takes us all quickly.___NEWPAGE___
lore-panopticonletters-piece2:
What is this mistreatment?!

I am Faris Hussain, heir to the throne of Derabul. I have come to expect better than this!
On a routine mercantile journey to share the finest silks with the world I find myself led down into a damp dark crevice.

My silks have been torn and turned to cleaning rags. Horrible! These brutish labourers would not know value if it stared them in the face. Yet I am stuck with them here. The lazarettos I have visited at least possessed some semblance of privacy, so what is this claim of quarantine? It is nonsense. I will have a word with these enforcers about granting me exit. They are certain to understand. Even if they do not, they will understand the wealth that awaits them for making exceptions for the exceptional.___NEWPAGE___
lore-panopticonletters-piece3:
After a journey so long and troublesome and the labor that followed I was hoping to rest, but I am not sure this is what I was asking for. Sitting still like so, it makes me antsy. I did not mind the work. The work is why I came here. A message came that workers were required, and I had wished to leave the city for a time now. My colleagues are a friendly and curious people. They have many questions of my lands, which I answer for them with glee!

When this all is over I will show them the giant rafflesia that grow plentifully around my home.___NEWPAGE___
lore-panopticonletters-piece4:
I have devised a plan of escape. Writing this record will help me commit it to memory and will surely drive these wardens mad with rage when they realize they have been outsmarted by the great Weasel!

I was never a good swimmer, but I can hold my breath for very long, and the old sewers are small enough to navigate by touch. My rotten hand still registers faint sensations. And the light pouring in through the grates will stand out in that impenetrable dark. Grates that are so rusty they will surely fall apart at my touch.

I will wait around for some-one or some other to inevitably draw the ire of the wardens. They like to gather everyone up, make this big spectacle. Under cover of this chaos I shall set my grand plan in motion, slip into the canals and unto the sewers, and warn the world of the injustices enacted by the Svanmarck family.___NEWPAGE___
lore-hopeandisaiahsledgers-piece1:
Day 1. Faulkner has ordered closure of all canal ingress points and instructed us to maintain order among the detained.

Approximately 43 detainees inside the reservoir at lockdown moment:
- 17 labourers
- 11 traders/boatmen
- 5 accompanying guards
- 6 miscellaneous travelers
- 4 children

Per Faulkner’s directive:
- No one exits until a cure is found.
- Anyone showing signs of lesions or fever is to be separated to the sick zone in the lower reservoir.
- No gatherings larger than six persons without warden supervision.

Rations have been seized, catalogued, and redistributed. Perishables - primarily fish from one highly disgruntled merchant - will last the first week if shared equitably. Merchant protested but complied after formal promise of compensation. Let us hope the quarantine resolves swiftly. 

Drafted by Isaiah
Confirmed by Hope___NEWPAGE___
lore-hopeandisaiahsledgers-piece2:
Day 7. Spirits are uneasy. Individuals demand answers we cannot give.

Two attempted to bribe passage through the south sluice. Sluice is jammed anyway - collapse from Faulkner’s blast. Both offenders placed in restricted quarters for twelve hours; released afterward with warning.

Faulkner requests written updates only. Claims he is “concentrating”.
We have asked for clear medical procedure and received nothing in return as of yet.

Standing water in the lower reservoir sick zone has already turned foul. Several of the initially isolated labourers have succumbed to disease overnight. We have begun herding detainees to sleep on the walkways to reduce exposure.

Child of the traveler Roland displays fever but no lesions. 
Roland pleaded for exemption; request granted on grounds that forced separation would incite further unrest. Both have been moved to the sick zone.

Drafted by Isaiah
Confirmed by Hope___NEWPAGE___
lore-hopeandisaiahsledgers-piece3:
Day 13. Fatigue increasing among both detainees and wardens.

Of the original 43 detained, 22 remain alive. Most recent losses occurred overnight in the sick zone.

The dead are piling up below, but with limited ventilation we cannot safely burn them. The sick that are still capable are ordered to move them to the collapsed tunnel until a permanent solution is found.

Three labourers attempted to bypass the walkway cordon during the night. Claimed they sought fresher air. Returned to designated area and reprimanded. 

The late Roland’s daughter asked us whether he would “wake once the air is clearer”. Informed this was a question for Faulkner.

Ration supplies remain stable, albeit at reduced allotment. With fewer individuals to feed, current stores may last much longer than projected.

First lesions observed on one of the accompanying guards previously assessed as healthy.
Isolated to the sick zone.

Still no medical procedure from Faulkner.

Drafted by Isaiah
Confirmed by Hope___NEWPAGE___
lore-hopeandisaiahsledgers-piece4:
Day 24? Day 25? The record must continue.

Population estimate: Nine remain in varying stages of decay.
Several are unable to stand. Most do not speak. Those who still breathe do so shallowly.
Movement between walkways has ceased. The sick zone is silent.

Faulkner has not responded to our last reports. We believe he has relocated deeper into the tunnels to continue his work.

Hope is… resting.
Their sight has fully left them, though they still turn their head when I speak.
My own condition is manageable. Previous attempts to doff my armor have resulted in torn skin.
Rot progressing along forearm and ribs. Pain intermittent.
Alas. The ledger is not for complaints.

Rations still adequate. Hardly consumed. No reason to maintain allotment schedule.

There is little more to report. Procedures remain in place with no-one left to enforce them upon. 
Still we hold our posts. It is what is expected of us. We have given everything we have to this duty and now there is nothing left.

I will play for Hope. On Faulkner’s piano. I will play a piece we both remember. I will burn it into my muscle memory if I need to, that I might still play it when I lose my own sight. And I pray to the Gods that this is the last thing we hear before the black sick takes our minds from us, too.

Drafted by Isaiah___NEWPAGE___
lore-treasurehunternotes1-piece1:
Meteoric iron is valuable and rare, and thus when I was a mere apprentice my master taught me always to keep an eye out for circular formations embedded in the soil.

Imagine my surprise, then, when I encounter a perfectly spherical absence of terrain in my travels, cut cleanly through a number of underground tunnels and rooms. I see nothing that could have led to this, and am not quite imaginative enough to theorize. Fortunately for how much of this complex seems to have been utterly annihilated the rest of it is left completely untouched, and I hope to find my answers within. The old coffers certainly won’t mind me helping myself to whatever equipment was left behind, either…

The sun is starting to set and I know better than to go poking around in these ruins without the sanctuary of daylight awaiting me outside, so I shall set up my camp and descend come the first light of dawn.___NEWPAGE___
lore-treasurehunternotes1-piece2:
This forsaken complex is labyrinthine. Of course it intrigues me, and I do not mind being lost here as much as I would some monotone caverns, but I can’t help but hope my explorations into the dark underbelly of this world are by far shorter than the subsequent taking inventory of my newfound treasures in the sun above.

I got my answers. Some of them, anyway. I rappelled down the edge of the crater into the shallowest tunnel, navigating the winding hallways until I found myself in what was left of a so-called Scriptorium. I can’t make sense of most of these diagrams, which tells me plenty in of itself; these people were messing with forces far beyond our comprehension, and my suspicion was swiftly confirmed as I approached the portion of the room that had been severed by the crater. Along its edge, tomes and scrolls were suspended in the air, floating. Where much of the parchment in the rest of this Scriptorium had yellowed with age, the pages of these books were a pristine white still. I did not dare further interact. Apparently I had the gift of self-restraint that these people had lacked.

That is something I would have liked to believe, and perhaps I did, at least until I heard a horrifying noise deeper into the complex and realized I had not bothered to pack a weapon. Not that I would ever willingly engage one of those monstrosities given the choice, but… well, I thought it best to head back towards the entrance. The noise did not seem to follow me, thank God, but as I stood at the entryway I heard the scraping of metal against stone out of a corridor marked Brickworks. For how foolish I was to head down unarmed, I wasn’t foolish enough to let these automatons overrun this facility in my absence, so I took to barricading the hallway. There was no short supply of furniture to do so with - these people must have lived garishly under their blue-and-green banner. With the promise of temporary safety I feel comfortable enough turning my back to these tunnels and ascending again, to return better-prepared in the near future.
lore-ripleysresearch-piece1:
These are the notes of head researcher Acantha Ripley, regarding her overseeing of the Temporal Calix Project.

How honoured I am, that the Goldfinches entrust a project of such import to my care. In these private writings I must admit I had felt as if my contributions went unnoticed as of late, that I was not trying hard enough. But God has listened and given me a chance to prove myself!

Now, this monumental occasion is just that- monumental. There are a great many things to do, and when fighting Time itself we cannot afford to tarry. We must find a way to generate massive amounts of energy in a small space - we must contain and direct it with minimal entropy - we must find a way to create boundaries in space that persist beyond space - all of these are tall orders, but none too great for the Goldfinch lineage, and all opportunities to prove that fraud Falx beneath us.

I must rally the greatest heads on the House grounds to my cause. Oh, certainly Rayleigh’s treatise on temporal entanglement will prove invaluable during the design stages, and even the late Magnus’ inventions - Gods bless his soul - will outlive him long beyond his Rotten body when we use it to construct our compact generators. The colleagues I have been assigned all show much promise, a deep interest in the prospect of stopping Time and loyalty to this House Most Noble. I have not felt such excitement since I graduated!___NEWPAGE___
lore-ripleysresearch-piece2:
These are the notes of head researcher Acantha Ripley, regarding the development of the Temporal Calix Project.

In all my excitement I forgot to cement the purpose of the Calix. Now that we have a rudimentary design, I may put my quill to paper once more, with certainty.

The Temporal Calix is a device that will create a hole in time and space, a bubble that offers sanctuary from the ever-encroaching Rot. The horticulturists upstairs are working on creating a perfect biosphere capable of sustaining life within itself indefinitely, and we downstairs are working on containing that biosphere outside of this world.

An order has been placed for an abundance of brickwork ingredients, the highest quality the Goldfinch estate can afford, that is to say, the highest quality available. Soon the olivine shipment will arrive on our doorstep and construction of the refraction chamber may begin.___NEWPAGE___
lore-ripleysresearch-piece3:
These are the notes of head researcher Acantha Ripley, regarding the setbacks of the Temporal Calix Project.

Frustrated. Some ne’er-do-well has sabotaged our translocator access to the nearest nexus, which would normally see use for quicker correspondence. Without it, every instruction, revision and authorization must crawl along the roads by courier, and nothing moves with the urgency this project requires.

I know better than to try to repair such a delicate device myself. That engineer Helen Shelley will need to come over again, and somehow I feel like the Svanmarck Estate has their hands full with the Rot on their own. It’s their roads the plague travels across, anyway.

The Blackguard foremen aren’t working their miners nearly hard enough and there is not enough coal for our Claw & Fang contact to divert to our warehouse unnoticed. We cannot fire the engine without fuel, and we cannot proceed with the prototypes until we generate enough power. I would almost think not all those working under our banner are as devoted to House Goldfinch as myself… and I would be happy to make an example out of them, could I afford to miss any hands working on this project. Unfortunately we are pressed for time, and for now these transgressions must go unpunished.

We have painstakingly agreed to purchase it directly from the Blackguard, but given the staff we need to send to fetch the coal and the tardiness of the miners we have half the personnel and no fuel to make progress with for days, if not weeks. Nevermind the serfs that will have to be disposed of at the gate if they catch the Rot…

At least this delay will let me go over the plans again and write up my report. I have directed the rest of my staff to aid the horticulturists in their efforts; I have received word of similar setbacks upon the surface, and I would like to dedicate myself wholly to my research… I find myself annoyed at how much time is lost managing others’ failures instead of dedicating myself to my craft.___NEWPAGE___
lore-ripleysresearch-piece4:
These are the notes of head researcher Acantha Ripley, regarding her doubts of the Temporal Calix Project.

Oh God, my God, let this not be in vain.

I am hesitant to admit I am experiencing doubts. All six serfs were shot by bowmen at the gate. I was called on to dispose of the bodies and decontaminate the coal-cart. I pray this is for my knowledge of sterile work, but I could not help but interpret it as a warning of what would become of me should I fail, thrust upon me by both the House itself and God.

With the ecstasy of constant discoveries absent, I find myself sober for the first time in days, staring at these plans and thinking them a madman’s. We do not have the means to generate the power required to contain the entirety of the biosphere. We wasted too much time waiting on the fuel… but the Rot did not wait.

Activation of the Calix is scheduled in a week from now. I cannot afford to lose faith in the process now. The halls beneath the House are abuzz with life once more as the project resumes, and there are so many people that depend on me here. More than ever I must double my efforts. I can rest within the Calix once it is complete… there is no more time to sleep.___NEWPAGE___
lore-ripleysresearch-piece5:
These are the notes of head researcher Acantha Ripley, regarding the activation of the Temporal Calix Project.

I find that my doubts have left me. Perhaps it is because the exhaustion took its place, or the gangrene on my feet from their lack of rest this week, but I do not possess the luxury of giving up on my charge. My people came through and everything is prepared for activation. The prototypes showed much promise. When we enter the Temporal Calix, I will celebrate with my peers and then sleep shamelessly at the banquet table! We have deserved our rest.

Everything is in place. The head of House Goldfinch has the honors of pulling the main power lever and being witness to the spawning of a sanctuary of our very own. They seem proud of our work at this moment, and I am certain now that it has all been worth it. Readings proceed as expected. The refraction chamber is managing to contain the massive quantities of energy with relative ease, when we were expecting at least minor fractures to form.

Curse these gangrenous legs of mine as I pass between stations to oversee the process. But I will have time to rest and recover shortly, by God, I know I will. The mirrors are directing the energies as expected, and the stabilizer is in place. No sight of any rifts. We are in the clear to activate.

We feel the ground tremble as the device springs to life. The world slows around us, but we do not. I become aware of my breathing, and then I become aware of it stopping, of hunger and exhaustion leaving me all at once. I see an intern moving towards us through the halls stopping, frozen in time. I realize now my mistake. The field generated is far too small. The power generated is far too little. Oh God, My God, please forgive me.
lore-stokersdirective-piece1:
Honoured Serf,
You have been selected to oversee the Stoking of the Grand Engine.
Part of this letter has been left blank to give you the room to drink in the importance of this duty, and to appreciate the honor bestowed upon you by receiving it.

…

You must be wondering what happened to your predecessor. House Goldfinch assures you the circumstances of the previous Stoker’s death were entirely unrelated to his line of work, and if Stoker Timm had chosen to spend more time within the safety of the engine room’s walls, he might have avoided his fate entirely.

As for technical information; to start up the Grand Engine from an inert state takes such an immense amount of energy that we have elected to simply leave it running constantly in a sort of “sleep” mode. At the rate at which this consumes fuel, it can continue running almost indefinitely, and it still generates enough power to light the facility.

Attached is a diagram of expected power requirements throughout the day.
Please contact the research team every morning to learn of their schedule for testing and additional power these tests will require. For any tests related to the Temporal Calix, disregard their own estimates and fire the engine at full power; this will require a steady stream of coal shoveled inside.

Automatons and untrained persons are not allowed inside the engine room due to the delicate nature of the Work. This is why the Stoking duty falls to you and you alone. Please ensure you remain in peak health so that you can continue to serve House Goldfinch as Stoker.

Do not, under any circumstances, let the engine run dry.
lore-brickworkerslament-piece1:
Everything automated through these locusts and helpers and the occasional eidolon, but still we must remain at our stations. To provide our “expertise”, but with no involvement in the process itself…
No, we are mere scapegoats for when the contraptions invariably fail. We are given tasks that are insultingly simple, yet leave us entirely responsible. It’s you who activated the automaton, so it’s you who are at fault for its failures.

I think I would have preferred if they had simply let us go, but instead we sit around waiting. Waiting for the inevitable shift the locusts break down again. Waiting to take the blame for their failure. Once in a blue moon, they are unable to find a brickworker to fault, and they seek answers among the engineers. I’d heard how those meetings go, once, in passing. Every shortcoming blamed on Jonas Falx, and in the same breath they claim still that their designs are entirely their own.
Are these engineers so proud that they refuse to consider the possibility their artifice needs improvement, that their imitations are imperfect? I came from a proud line of masons, myself, but I take pride in stonework that can stand the test of time, not whatever novel trinket most impresses Gage Goldfinch.

I must remain in their good graces, though. During that same meeting I learned the Calix is nearing completion, and that soon we will all be living lives free of worry. So I will clench my teeth a little longer and turn on the automatons at the start of all my shifts, and pray to God that they keep working, so that I may keep working here in turn.
lore-agitatedregards-piece1:
Ripley, this has to stop. I understand that you think your projects are important but I would think keeping the House Head happy and fed is quite important in its own right. In all of our best interests, in fact! I just watched Goldfinch fire another serf after he offered them grapes deemed too small. A choking hazard. There’s not many servants left to take the fall for me before I end up having to present the fruits and vegetables in person.

I keep reaching for the saltpeter to fashion my fertilizer and finding the vessels empty. When you use the last of something, you put in an order for more. That is how things work around here. I understand this is your first time as research head, but we cannot afford for you to make these mistakes. I spent years training in the Derabul academy to trim hedges and sprout flowers, never to grow crops, let alone enough produce to feed the entire staff. And I will admit I have dreamt more than once of working on the Askannon orchards instead. But regardless I have taken on my new duties swimmingly. Why can’t you do the same?

The leatherworker, bless her soul, accused me of having used too much! Yet my fields have never looked worse, and I know my green fingers are not to blame. Whatever you’re doing down there had better be worth the trouble you’re causing up in the House by so carelessly draining our reagents. I have put in another order of niter, twice the size as usual, and I implore you to leave some for the rest of us this time.

With agitated regards,
Basira Qamar,
Head Horticulturist of House Goldfinch

___NEWPAGE___
lore-smashingsuccess-piece1:
Gertrude sent me here with her own blend of gunpowder. Said the estate had no nitre left and that this was all of it, so I was not to waste a grain. I was to send lit explosives through the translocators to destroy the far ends, then smash the mechanisms here by hand. I was to sever the roads so the Rot could not travel.

I was so proud to be trusted with it! Proud that she chose me for the job. The work went smoothly, and I had just about finished. I remember thinking I’d like to see the fruits of my labor on the other sides of the translocators.

What a fool I was to have that thought, because it shortly came true. The Goldfinch translocator flared to life. A bomb came through, lit, packed just like she had taught me to do during the briefing.

I understand now why she insisted I use that device to arrive here. Why she told me to stick around after I was done to make sure the Translocator Nexus had become entirely inoperational. I’ve been exposed to the Rot. I’ve breathed the air here for too long. She could not risk letting me return. This was never meant to be a round trip. Nevertheless, I have destroyed what I can reach. These translocators will not carry the Rot any farther.

Gertrude Goldfinch was my patron, my employer, and in the end, my executioner. I do not curse her for it. I only wish she had not let me believe I was coming home.

Michael Richardson
lore-severancenotice-piece1:
Helen Shelley of the Clockwork Guild,

By order of the Svanmarck Estate, effective immediately, the Askannon endpoint is to be removed from the Translocator Nexus routing lattice.

The Askannons have failed to remit their agreed dues for the last two quarters, despite repeated notice. As such, their access is revoked until payment is settled in full, with penalty.

You are to ensure that any existing connection to the Askannon holding is rendered inactive and that no further traffic may be directed there under the Estate’s authority. No replacement destination is to be advertised from this location without written approval.

The public-facing arrangement above is not to be disturbed. Any inquiries are to be redirected through the usual channels and dismissed as a matter of scheduling or maintenance. This action is administrative in nature and does not constitute a dissolution of contract, only a suspension of privileges.

Signed,
Elewyn of Svanmarck
lore-quarrycorrespondences-piece1:
Gage’s Instructions

Foreman Jack Foster,

Your appointment reflects our confidence in your discretion as much as your competence. This operation requires both.

This site exists to extract salt and potash. It must continue to do so in a manner that is utterly and totally unremarkable. It does not need to be profitable.

That said, you are already aware that our houses have carried with them an unresolved matter for some time now. Your secondary objective is to retrieve the Authoritative Copy of a trade agreement made between the former matriarchs Gertrude Goldfinch and Anastasia of Svanmarck. It is believed to be contained within a wax-sealed brass scroll case as was standard Undland practice at the time.

Enclosed with this letter you will find a document. It is a report of the failed Hunt by your wildfolk colleagues, commissioned at the time of the Undland Arbiter’s disappearance. Use it to determine where the Authoritative Copy was lost.

It will also make plain the degree to which the Svanmarck Estate has wronged us, and why I am so intent on seeing this noble dispute settled. They have won over us in court with a forgery of the agreement and demanded unreasonable tolls to use the roads on our own lands for many years now.

The Copy will allow us to force arbitration anew and strip the Estate of its standing.

House Svanmarck will continue to observe our operations. Treat their auditors as collaborators, not adversaries. Any overt conflict would defeat the purpose of this venture. If staff is lost and retrieval proves impossible without drawing attention, abandonment of the site is preferable.

With golden grace,
Gage Goldfinch

___NEWPAGE___
lore-quarrycorrespondences-piece2:
Arbiter Hunt Pawprint

Hard to miss this arbiter fellow, the way he was dressed. Spotted the scroll case on him right away and stopped the cart. He declined surrender and fled towards the Salt Mouth, some old swallow hole that water’s been disappearing into for years. Looks like it’s taken a liking to Undland lackeys as well.

Whether he broke his neck on the way down or drowned doesn’t much matter. He’s dead, and the sealed agreement went with him. No getting that back without putting our own lives on the line, and you’re not paying us enough to.

We dealt with the rest of them cleanly. Guards, attendants, the whole lot. Stacked the bodies in their own cart and sent it tumbling into the Salt Mouth too. Wasn’t anybody else on the road to see it happen.

We didn’t recover your document. Call it a failure if you like, but nobody else on God’s green earth will be able to get their hands on it either. Nothing that goes into that pit has ever come back out, not in living memory. No copy and no witnesses means no dispute. You can do what you set out to do all the same.

No further action is required from the Claw & Fang, and we expect full payment at this drop-off before month’s end.

Isaak of Koritok

___NEWPAGE___
lore-quarrycorrespondences-piece3:
Natalya’s Inspection Memo

Addressed to J. Foster,

I have completed my most recent inspection of the halite quarry and its surrounding works. I will admit to some relief at finding nothing of particular note. The operation is exactly as it claims to be; a modest halite and potash site, competently run, and of no especial interest to the Svanmarck Estate beyond its continued compliance.

I cannot help but remark on the figures. The costs of operation appear to outweigh the returns by a comfortable margin. I imagine this would be far more concerning if House Goldfinch were not so well-positioned elsewhere. Still, it is curious to see a noble house expend this much effort for so little gain. I can't say I miss the days where old Gertrude stood at the head of your House, but the Goldfinches were certainly more of a force to be reckoned with during that time. It's no matter. I know you have enough in your coffers to survive until Gage finally grows up.

The access roads remain in good condition, thanks in no small part to Svanmarck maintenance. Given the remoteness of the site, I would encourage a greater appreciation for the infrastructure that allows materials, equipment and workers to reach it all. Without our continued oversight, I suspect operations here would be considerably more difficult.

Conditions underground are adequate, if somewhat lax. Drainage channels have been cut with great enthusiasm and too little care, and several supports show signs of wear. I recommend addressing these issues in due time, though I trust you understand that any major improvements to access or reinforcement will require coordination with the Estate, and may not be prioritized given broader regional needs.

In summary, the quarry presents no cause for concern. It is dull, inefficient, and largely beneath notice. I see no indication of secretive extraction of rare metals as my superiors had suspected, and no reason for further scrutiny at this time. Do extend my regards to your workers. They seem diligent, if perhaps overly optimistic about the future of this venture.

Under eye of the Crown of Undland,
Natalya of Svanmarck
Auditor in service to the Svanmarck Estate

___NEWPAGE___
lore-quarrycorrespondences-piece4:
Unsent Letter

To Gage Goldfinch of the House Most Splendorous,

I am writing this for the sake of record, if nothing else.

The storm damage is worse than expected. The lower shafts are flooded beyond what the pumps can manage, and the exploratory cuts we discussed have been compromised with workers inside. A recovery effort would require additional hands, additional time, and additional movement across the access roads.

Given the Estate’s continued oversight, I cannot see a way to proceed without inviting questions we are not prepared to answer.

The men trapped below were working sections not listed on the primary survey. Any attempt to retrieve them would require admitting to those works. I assume you understand the implications better than I do.

I will do what I was appointed to do and see the site closed cleanly.
Natalya already considers the quarry unremarkable and the storm makes a perfect cover.

J. Foster
lore-authoritativecopy-piece1:
This document constitutes a faithful and binding record of the trade agreement entered into by the Svanmarck Estate and House Goldfinch, under the eye of the Crown of Undland and with the assent of its appointed Arbiter, to govern matters of passage, access, and non-interference between the two houses.

House Svanmarck affirms its sole authority over the construction, maintenance, and operation of roads, canals, and other regional infrastructure within Goldfinch lands and holdings.

House Goldfinch is granted permanent and preferential access to all Svanmarck-maintained infrastructure required for the transport of goods, materials, and persons between Goldfinch holdings and points of trade.

House Goldfinch and its interests shall not need to pay tolls on roads on its own territory. Access to Svanmarck infrastructure shall not otherwise be withheld, restricted, or made conditional beyond maintenance fees as fixed at the time of signing, except by direct sanction of the Crown of Undland.

House Svanmarck shall ensure reasonable maintenance and timely repair of said infrastructure where it services Goldfinch routes, and shall not delay or neglect such maintenance for the purpose of leverage, pressure, or advantage.

House Svanmarck affirms non-interference in the internal operations, extraction, and trade practices of House Goldfinch, and shall not employ its control of infrastructure to influence, hinder, or extract additional concessions from Goldfinch interests.

House Goldfinch recognizes the Svanmarck Estate as the sole authority over regional infrastructure, and agrees not to construct or commission competing roads, canals, or transit works within Goldfinch territory.

This agreement is witnessed and sealed under authority of the Crown of Undland, signed threefold by representatives of their respective noble houses.
lore-saltstainedscrawlings-piece1:
First entry

We expected Jackal to pull out every stop to get us out of here. We really did. He was one hell of a taskmaster but we knew in our hearts that he cared for us. He joined us in song and striking at salt. You just know he was a labourer once.

That’s why I wish I could say any of us are surprised by this outcome. Hale says he spent three days or so trapped inside a coal mine once and the only reason they freed him is because they wanted to get to the vein he was stuck with. But we’ve all heard the conversations between Jackal and that Svanmarck woman. The quarry isn’t turning a profit. They’re not coming back for us.

___NEWPAGE___
lore-saltstainedscrawlings-piece2:
Second entry

The pumps were never turned back on, we don’t think. The water just keeps finding new ways in.

We can hear water running somewhere up ahead, after we heard a collapse from the same direction. It’s hard to keep time down here. Maybe we ought to have had more faith in Jackal. We’re going to pick up our tools and continue digging in that direction. 

Elna is insisting he knows old Foster wouldn’t leave us if he had a choice, but Joren keeps saying that’s not his choice to make in the first place.

___NEWPAGE___
lore-saltstainedscrawlings-piece3:
Final entry

The sound led us true enough.

We broke into a wide hollow, lost two good people in doing so, and for a moment we thought we’d done it. The air actually moved here, and the water had places to drain into. There are bones down here. Old ones, piled and scattered, half-buried in salt and silt. Whatever this place used to be, it wasn’t a way out. Is this what they had sent us looking for?

The ceiling is too high to climb, and the walls are too slick, and we are all so exhausted. I am choosing to believe Jackal doesn’t know we’re here. I pray to God that the others will let me have this small comfort before this cavity becomes our tomb, as well.

Being the only one out of the four of us who knows how to write, I’m going to jot down what we’d want said, in case they realize we are missing and come for us too late.

___NEWPAGE___
lore-saltstainedscrawlings-piece4:
Farewells

This is for Elric and the boys.
I thought I would come home with salt money and sore hands and that would be all.
I’m sorry I did not. I love you more than I ever said.
Above anything, do not let them tell you I was careless.
Hale

For my sister Mara.
Keep the house if you can. Do not sell it even if they pressure you. I worked hard to get us a roof over our heads in Yarrowford. I only wish I could be buried there instead of here. And more than that I hope this text never has to see the light of day, and that rescue will break through these walls shortly.
Please tell Father I forgive him. I don’t think I was ever angry with him.
Elna

To my mother: I’m sorry to have worried you so much. I reckon I’m responsible for more than a few of your grey hairs, and I’d be surprised if you didn’t have a head full by the time you hear about the closing. I fear old age will have taken you long before we’re found, but I still find some catharsis in imagining you reading this someday.
Your bread is still the greatest thing that I’ve ever tasted, and the memory of it has carried me through the roughest of shifts with a smile on my face.
Joren

For Tomas
I just know you will be angry when you hear this. Put it to good use for once and fix the roof. Roland and the girls will appreciate it. The leakage is worse on the eastern side. You’ll find it easily after the thaw.
Lina

___NEWPAGE___
lore-pawprints-piece1:
No can do. We’re mercenaries, not a warband, and we don’t intend to make ourselves this big of a target.

Besides, the Svanmarck Estate is a loyal customer of ours. It’d be most regrettable if news reached them that you attempted to have their matriarch killed outright, but I reckon we might just forget about it real conveniently if you pay off your debts to us before the next full moon.

What made you think we were going to take on more work while you had an open tab, anyway?

Isaak of Koritok

___NEWPAGE___
lore-pawprints-piece2:
I beseech you, wicked wolves of the wilds! 

My boy was taken prisoner just a sunrise ago by roadside robbers. I barely got away with my life. They’re asking a ransom much greater than what I can pay, so instead I will offer all that I do have to you, heirlooms of mine and mine ancestors.

Please return my boy to me safely. I care not what happens to the slavers. They are camped out a thousand paces or so down the road to Erak ambushing caravans.

___NEWPAGE___
lore-pawprints-piece3:
Indrinaak, I need your advice.

The Askannon job is beginning to move out of scope. They just keep buying up low-value land. What little coin they manage to scrape together vanishes into more holdings. I can’t tell what they intend to do with all of it.

As a result, I’m struggling to keep eyes on Havald. Made none the easier by the fact he moves among his people like some commoner, without a fixed residence to follow him from or jewelry to make him stand out. It all makes him exceedingly hard to track.

Jackal

___NEWPAGE___
lore-pawprints-piece4:
Found the cache disturbed but empty. Visited Nicola and she insisted on her life that she’d paid her dues. She’s not stupid enough to lie about this stuff.

Damn these scavengers. I think it might be that defector Weasel. They’ve been too much of a nuisance as of late anyway, dragging our good name through the mud. I’ll be driving them out of town personally.

Indrinaak

___NEWPAGE___
lore-pawprints-piece5:
Isaak, I don’t think I can sleep until I see some sign, anything, that this is all over. That after years of strife I found the right people to solve this problem and that they have solved it rightly once and for all and that I can rest again, truly rest, knowing that me and my charges are safe.

I want to take your word for it, truly I do, but the nightmares have not left me. Please feel free to ignore my ramblings, for I own nothing more to pay you with. But I beg of you, if you could, leave evidence here. A token taken off of his person. I just need to see proof, I won’t take it from the cache, and if I do you know where to find me.

___NEWPAGE___
lore-pawprints-piece6:
Is there anybody left?

The world has shifted. I scarcely recognize any of it. But I do recognize our sigil. I didn’t think any would have survived the Rot. But now the Rot is gone.
The roads I used to prowl have disappeared. I don’t see the city walls on the distant horizon. Nor the silhouette of its towers rising far above them. Am I still in Undland?

There’s just… trees and grass. There was a time where I would’ve wanted nothing more for the world, but I realize immediately just how much I miss the people. If anybody finds this, I am starting to travel eastward looking for other survivors, and I ask you to follow me.

Indrinaak

___NEWPAGE___
lore-pawprints-piece7:
Is this how the people of the Old World communicated? It feels silly, leaving notes below trees. I wonder what you would think of us, continuing your traditions.

Perhaps not your traditions exactly. We use your symbol now as trail markers. And we use them to exchange gifts with each-other. It’s customary to take something and leave something behind. I found my favorite toy in this cache. A clay figurine of a hound.

Some of us use them as places of worship. Hard to find churches on the road! My Nana taught me to always carry a knife on my person, to touch up the carvings when I can. I reckon this was important to you. I hope that someday when I’m gone, those that come after me will look after what I left behind, as well.

Amah

dialogue-ahyouhavecometotherightplace: Ah, you’ve come to the right person. I deal in opportunities most wouldn’t dare entertain. Tell me - are you the sort who seeks the rare and the extraordinary? dialogue-forlornhope1: The Forlorn Hope were a legendary order of warriors, handpicked by kings and lords for the most impossible tasks. These were soldiers who thrived where others faltered - masters of combat, feared and respected alike. Their name alone could inspire loyalty in allies and terror in enemies. This tower was one of their strongholds, a place where they trained, stored their spoils, and forged their plans. If the stories hold any truth, treasures of their time might still remain within its walls.
dialogue-forlornhope2: A good question. Towers like this were built as fortresses, not just to protect, but to endure. dialogue-forlornhope3: This map isn’t something I part with lightly. For 10 rusty gears, it’s yours. A fair price for a guide to potential riches, wouldn’t you agree?
dialogue-buyforlornmap1: So, do you have the 10 rusty gears ready for trade? This is an offer I won’t make twice.

dialogue-strategy3: Funny you ask! I've got a distinct request from a long-time customer. They're in search of a large intact Globe, as a present for their friend. Think you might stumble upon something like that in your travels?
dialogue-strategy4.1: I'll keep my eyes peeled for a large globe.
dialogue-strategy4.2: Im quite busy at the moment sorry. Maybe another time.

dialogue-takeglobe:
You've managed to find the Globe?! I see. Let me have a closer look at this remarkable piece.

(He carefully examines the Globe, tracing the intricate lines with a finger and studying the faded maps.)
dialogue-globediscussion:
Incredible craftsmanship, truly a relic of its time. But there's something here, a mark that has piqued my curiosity.

(The Trader continues to scrutinize the Globe, his brow furrowing slightly as he examines a particular spot on the map.)
dialogue-globediscussion1:
Is there something of significance,
something that has caught your attention?
dialogue-globediscussion2:
Indeed, my friend. Look here, at this specific mark. It seems deliberate, unlike the usual cartographic details. It appears to point to a grand structure - a university, if the rumors are to be believed. It’s said to be nestled in a ravine, surrounded by remnants of an old village. And here...

(He taps on the map with a finger.)

...a tower, likely part of the university. Such places often hold secrets worth uncovering. If you’re bold enough to explore it, who knows what treasures you might find?
dialogue-globediscussion3:
A university in a ravine?
That does sound intriguing.
What could it possibly signify?
dialogue-globediscussion4:
That’s the question, isn’t it? Some claim it was a place of immense learning, where scholars and visionaries gathered. Others whisper that it housed forbidden knowledge - texts and artifacts deemed too dangerous for the world outside. Whatever the truth, it has long been abandoned, and the ruins are likely teeming with opportunities for those daring enough to venture there.

(He pauses, his expression thoughtful.)
dialogue-globediscussion5:
I’ll need to bring this Globe to my customer, but before I do, let me copy down the markings.

(The trader carefully examines the Globe, tracing the intricate details with a quill onto a piece of parchment.)

There - this map should guide you to that university. What treasures or knowledge lie there, I cannot say, but it’s bound to be worth your while. If you find anything valuable, bring it back - I’m always interested in rare artifacts.
dialogue-globediscussion6: And as promised, here's your well-earned reward of 10 rusty gears for bringing me the globe. Thank you very much!
